hints.content: Start by understanding how to iterate through both strings simultaneously. You can use a loop that runs for the length of the shorter string to merge characters alternately.
Consider using an index to track your position in each string. You can increment this index for each character you add to the merged string.
Remember to handle the case where one string is longer than the other. After merging the characters alternately, you will need to append the remaining characters from the longer string.
To merge the strings, you might want to initialize an empty result string or a list to collect the characters before joining them at the end.
Think about how you can concatenate characters from both strings. You can use string slicing or simply access characters by their indices.
When you reach the end of the shorter string, check the length of both strings. Use an if statement to determine which string has remaining characters.
You can use a loop that runs up to the maximum length of both strings. Inside the loop, add characters from both strings based on their current index.
Make sure to handle edge cases, such as when both strings are of equal length or when one string is empty. What should your function return in these cases?
Consider using a single loop that runs through the indices of both strings up to the maximum length. Use conditional checks to append characters from each string.
Your final merged string should be constructed by combining characters from both strings in the correct order. Remember to return the result at the end of your function.

questionNotes: Both word1 and word2 consist of lowercase English letters.
Return the merged string in the specified format.
